choices.text: Glucose is transported via passive diffusion
Co- transport is mediated with the use of carriers
Active transport is an energy dependent process

questions.text: ALL except the following are true –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


 Facilitated diffusion requires carrier protein but not dependent on energy.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man is brought to the Emergency with complaints of nausea, vomiting, muscle cramps, and generalized weakness. Laboratory analysis reveals significant hyperkalemia. Elevations of extracellular potassium ion concentration will have which of the following effects on the nerve membranes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

RMP becomes less negative

In hyperkalemia, the potassium gradient between the inside and outside the cell decreases. This reduces the rate of potassium efflux resulting in more positive ions inside the cell. This causes the RMP to become less negative or the cell depolarizes.

questions.text:
A patient has a resting heart rate of 70 beats/min, normal blood pressure, and normal body temperature. Use the pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle below to answer Question

What is the cardiac output of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cardiac output can be calculated by multiplying SV times heart rate.If stroke volume is 100 ml and heart rate is 70 beats/min, then 100 × 70 =7000 ml/min.

choices.text: From point D to point A
From point A to point C
From point D and point B

questions.text:
A patient has a resting heart rate of 70 beats/min, normal blood pressure, and normal body temperature. Use the pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle below to answer Question

What is the extent of diastole in the ventricular pressure-volume relationship?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Diastole includes the isovolumetric relaxation period (D to A) and ventricular filling (A-AV valve opening- to B -AV valve closure-). Thus, the diastole extends from point D to point B.

questions.text: A muscle has 140 mM of a bivalent cation present extracellularly while the intracellular concentration of the same cation is 14 mM. Assuming that 2.3 RT/F = 60 mV, what would be the membrane potential if the membrane were permeable to only this ion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


Equilibrium potential (mV) = 2.3 RT/FZ * log C1/C2 
Since it is a bivalent ion, Z = 2
Therefore, the equilibrium potential is 
= (60/2) log140/14
= 30 X log10
= 30mV
Since the membrane is freely permeable to the cation, the ion moves from outside to inside the cell. The inside of the cell becomes positive w.r.t outside. This positive potential inside the cell stops further movement of the cation to reach equilibrium. The potential at equilibrium will, therefore, be +30mV.

questions.text: A 80-year-old male with emphysema presents for his annual pulmonary function testing to assess the progression of the disease. As a result of alveolar septal de-partitioning in emphysema, there is a decrease in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Diffusing capacity

Breakdown of alveolar walls (alveolar septal departitioning) and loss of pulmonary capillaries in emphysema decreases the surface area available for diffusion causing a decrease in diffusing capacity.

questions.text: Which of the following are best suited to measure the interstitial fluid volume?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Inulin and Evan’s Blue
Measurement of IF is indirect. IF = ECF- Plasma.  Inulin is the most accurate for measurement of ECF volume and Evan’s blue is used for Plasma volume. 
Radioactive sodium is used for ECF measurement. 
Radioactive iodine labelled albumin is used for measurement of plasma volume.

questions.text: A patient with blood glucose level of 200mg/dL and GFR of 90mL/min. The transport maximum of the patient is as shown in the picture given below. What is the amount of glucose excreted?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: In infants, defecation often follows a meal. The cause of colonic contractions in this situation is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


Distension of the stomach by food initiates contractions of the rectum and, frequently, a desire to defecate. The response is called the gastrocolic reflex, and may be amplified by an action of gastrin on the colon. Because of the response, defecation after meals is the rule in children. In adults, habit and cultural factors play a large role in determining when defecation occurs.

questions.text: Water is absorbed in the jejunum, ileum, and colon and excreted in the feces. Arrange these in order of the amount of water absorbed or excreted from greatest to smallest.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


The input into the GI tract is approximately 9000mL per day (Oral intake- 2000mL, GI secretions- 7000mL). Out of this 5500mL is absorbed in the jejunum, 2000mL in the ileum and 1300mL in the colon. Balance 200mL is lost in stool.

questions.text: Regional variations in ventilation (V) and perfusion (Q) are measured in healthy individuals when they stand in the upright position. The results are graphed with x-axis denoting the position along the lung from the base to the apex. Which of the curves is most likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Ventilation and blood flow decrease from base to apex but the V/Q ratio increases from base to apex.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones has a nuclear receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Thyroid
Estrogen and thyroid hormones have nuclear receptors. All other lipid-soluble hormones- glucocorticoids, aldosterone, testosterone, progesterone have cytoplasmic receptors.

questions.text: A normal 20-year-old male breathes in as much air as he can and then exhales as much air as possible. The lung volume at maximum inspiration is 6.0L, and the lung volume after maximum expiration is 1.0L. His tidal volume at rest is 0.5L, and his functional residual capacity is 3.5L. What is his vital capacity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

5.0L

Forced vital capacity or vital capacity is the volume of air expired forcefully after a forceful inspiration. FVC = TLC – RV = 6.0 – 1.0 = 5.0L.

choices.text: SCFAs are produced in colon by the action of colonic bacteria on complex carbohydrates, resistant starches and dietary fiber
SCFAs are absorbed in the colon
SCFAs are absorbed by Na-SCFA co transport

questions.text: All of the following are true about short chain fatty acids except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


SCFAs are produced in colon by the action of colonic bacteria on complex carbohydrates, resistant starches and dietary fiber and are absorbed in the colon. 60% of total is acetate, 25% propionate, and 15% butyrate. Absorbed SCFAs are metabolized and make a significant contribution to the total caloric intake. They exert a trophic effect on the colonic epithelial cells. SCFAs are absorbed by specific transporters present in colonic epithelial cells.

choices.text: Shift in the OHDC to the right

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with a history of depression attempts suicide by locking herself in car with the ignition on and the exhaust connected with a pipe to the cabin of the car. She is found comatose in her car by her husband and is brought to the Emergency of a nearby hospital. Which of the following changes are likely to occur to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Decrease in Hb saturation
The patient has CO poisoning. In Co poisoning the saturation of Hb is reduced, but the dissolved oxygen is normal. CO decreases glycolysis, reducing 2,3-BPG and causing a shift OHDC to the left.

questions.text: What is the best way to maintain blood flow to a tissue?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


Flow is directly proportional to the fourth power of radius. Increasing the vessel diameter will cause the largest increase in flow.

choices.text: Control and co-ordinate movements of the axial muscles, as well as the shoulder and hip
Control and co-ordinate movements of the distal limb muscles
Function with the cerebral cortex to plan motor movements
Maintain balance and co-ordinate eye movements

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the functional role of the medial lobe of the cerebellum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Control and co-ordinate movements of the axial muscles, as well as the shoulder and hip. 
The medial lobe (vermis) coordinates the axial muscles and is a part of the spinocerebellum.

questions.text: Discharge from baroreceptors causes inhibition of –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Discharge from baroreceptors occurs when there is more stretching of baroreceptors so these decrease discharge of RVLM( pressor area in medulla ) and will lower BP.

questions.text: The distance by which two stimuli must be separated to be perceived as two separate stimuli is greatest at-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation- merkel disk receptors are located farthest at the back of scapula.

questions.text: Tendon organ, correct is all except –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation- tendon reflex afferent is Ib fibers.

questions.text: Secretion of which of the following substances is inhibited by low pH?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation- Gastrin causes release of gastric juice from stomach in gastric phase, its secretion is under negative feedback control.

questions.text: Which of the following functions of the Sertoli cells mediates negative feedback control of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation- Inhibin is produced by the Sertoli cells of the testes when they are stimulated by follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). Inhibin then inhibits further secretion of FSH by negative feedback on the anterior pituitary. The Leydig cells synthesize testosterone. Testosterone is aromatized in the ovaries.

questions.text: The inability to perceive the texture & shape an object occurs in lesion of-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Astereognosis is impaired or lost ability to discriminate between various forms, as well as deficits in finger localization and in graphesthesia (ability to recognize palm writing). If a lesion occurs at or above the level of the thalamus, it commonly results in astereognosis. Since Nucleus cuneatus gets information from T5 upwards including the upper limb, its lesion results in astereognosis.

questions.text: Which of the following organs has the highest arterio-venous oxygen differences under normal conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Heart

Heart has a very high oxygen demand at rest. Because of the high rate of metabolism in the heart compared with its blood flow, it has the highest arterio-venous oxygen difference under normal conditions. The heart can extract a large amount of oxygen because of its high capillary density.

questions.text: During which interval of the ECG does the aortic valve close?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


Aortic valve closes when the ventricles begin to relax and the intra- ventricular pressure becomes lower than the aortic pressure. Ventricular repolarization, represented by the T wave, is followed by ventricular relaxation.

choices.text: Both releasing and inhibitory hypothalamic hormones

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman visits her physician complaining of amenorrhea, headaches, profuse sweating, and joint pains associated with changes in the size of her hands and feet. The patient reports significant increase in the size of her hands and feet, as well as protrusion of her lower jaw. She first noticed these changes about 6 months ago when she was home for the holidays and saw some early college pictures of herself. After that, she says she became more aware of her bodily changes. The usual mechanism of hypothalamic control of the abnormal hormone in this patient is by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Both releasing and inhibitory hypothalamic hormones
The patient has features suggestive of Acromegaly due to excessive growth hormone secretion. 
GH is a peptide released from the anterior pituitary. The hypothalamus secretes two peptides that control GH release: growth hormone–releasing hormone (GHRH) and somatostatin, which is also called growth hormone–inhibiting hormone (GHIH). The main hypothalamic hormone controlling GH secretion is GHRH and not Somatostatin. 
GH acts directly on multiple tissues to increase blood glucose and also stimulates the hepatic release of IG- 1 (Somatomedin C), which mediates growth in numerous tissues.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is in the second post operative day after a hysterectomy. She suddenly stands after being supine since the day of the operation. As a result, which of the following hemodynamic variables will increase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ejection fraction

On standing up from a lying position causes a decrease in venous return, cardiac output, stroke volume and blood pressure. Baroreceptor reflex increases sympathetic outflow which increases the total peripheral resistance, cardiac contractility, stroke volume, heart rate and ejection fraction. These changes in the cardiovascular system return the blood pressure toward normal.

choices.text: ANP secretion increases with increase in central venous pressure

questions.text: An 80-year-old man presents with dyspnoea, which worsens with exertion. The cardiologist orders an echocardiogram, BNP and ANP levels to evaluate possible cardiac failure. Which of the following is most likely to occur with ANP?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

ANP secretion increases with increase in central venous pressure
Increase in blood volume, increase in central venous pressure or increased plasma sodium concentration stimulate the atrial stretch receptors which in turn increase secretion of ANP and decrease secretion of ADH. ANP causes a simultaneous afferent arteriolar dilatation and efferent arteriolar constriction, increasing the GFR. It decreases salt and therefore, water reabsorption producing natriuresis and diuresis.

questions.text: Two bubbles X and Y have the same surface tension, but bubble X has 2 times the diameter of bubble Y. The ratio of the pressure in bubble X to that in bubble Y is-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

0.5:1

According to La Place’s Law, Tension = Distending pressure * radius or Pressure = T/r. in other words, the distending pressure is inverse to the radius. Bubble X, which has 2 times the radius of bubble Y, will therefore, have half of the pressure in bubble Y.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has a mass in the sella turcica that compresses the portal vessels, disrupting pituitary access to hypothalamic secretions. The secretion rate of which hormone would most likely increase in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prolactin

Prolactin secretion is inhibited by hypothalamic PIF. All others are stimulated by hypothalamic hormones.  Obstruction of blood flow through the hypothalamic- hypophyseal portal vessels would lead to reduced secretion of ACTH, TSH, GH, FSH, LH, but increased secretion of Prolactin.

questions.text: Adequate oxygen delivery at cellular level is present in which type of hypoxia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Histotoxic hypoxia refers to a reduction in ATP production by the mitochondria due to a defect in the cellular usage of oxygen while the delivery to tissues is normal. The problem lies with extraction.

questions.text: All of the following increase vasopressin secretion EXCEPT?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Which part of thalamus is related to motor control?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ventrolateral and Ventroanterior nuclei Motor function. They receive input from basal ganglia and cerebellum and project to motor nucleus.

questions.text: In the figure shown below- A 22-year-old woman inhales as much air as possible and exhales as much air as she can, producing the spirogram shown in the figure. A residual volume of 1.0 liter is determined using the helium dilution technique. What is her FRC (in liters)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In the figure given above RV is 1 L & ERV is 2 L so FRC WILL BE 3 Ls.

questions.text: Not a part of basal ganglia is-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The subfornical organ (SFO), situated on the ventral surface of the fornix (the reasoning behind the organ’s name), at the interventricular foramina (foramina of Monroe), is one of the circumventricular organs of the brain, meaning that it is highly vascularized and does not have a blood-brain barrier, unlike the vast majority of regions in the brain.

questions.text: The migrating motor complex is triggered by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Motilin secreted by the M cells of the small intestine is responsible for the migrating motor complexes, which occur in the interdigestive period. In the period between meals, the intestine is relatively quiescent, but every 90 min or so it is swept through by a large peristaltic wave triggered by the hormone motilin. This migrating motor complex presumably serves a “housekeeping” function.

questions.text: A patient with pulmonary vascular disease has mean pulmonary artery pressure and venous pressure of 33- and 3-mm Hg, respectively, while the cardiac output is 3 L/ minute. What is the pulmonary vascular resistance in mm Hg/ L/ min?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

10 

Flow = ∆P/ R

Resistance = ∆P/ Flow = (33 – 3)/ 3 = 30/3 = 10 mm Hg/L/min.

questions.text: The transport of H+ ions into the proximal tubule is primarily associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reabsorption of bicarbonate

In the PCT, for every H+ ion secreted, one bicarbonate is reabsorbed (indirect reabsorption of bicarbonate).

choices.text: Transport into the tubular epithelial cell in the kidney
Transport into the intestinal epithelial cells

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with recurrent vaginal candidiasis. Screening shows elevated blood glucose, and the patient is started on 25 units of Insulin per day. Which aspect of glucose transport will be enhanced by the insulin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Transport into adipocytes
Insulin facilitates glucose entry into adipocytes, resting skeletal muscle cells, cardiac muscle cells and some smooth muscle cells by increasing the number of Glut-4 transport proteins in the membrane of these cells. Insulin does not enhance glucose transport into brain cells, intestinal epithelial cells or renal tubular epithelial cells.

questions.text: Which of the following reflexes is correctly paired with its receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Autogenic inhibition- Golgi tendon organ

Receptors for the stretch reflex (also k/a myotactic reflex or deep tendon jerk) are the muscle spindles. Reciprocal inhibition is also mediated by the muscle spindles. Receptors for the inverse stretch reflex (also k/a autogenic inhibition) are the Golgi tendon organs. Nociceptor stimulation is responsible for the flexor withdrawal and the crossed extensor responses.
